quotation: Our outlook for unemployment is worse than the Greenbook's because of firms' persistent caution in hiring full-time U.S. employees.
description: Unemployment outlook is worse than Greenbook forecast due to firms' persistent hiring caution
explanation: A more pessimistic unemployment forecast than the baseline, caused by persistent hiring caution, supports maintaining accommodative policy to address weak employment conditions

quotation: But still, I'm fairly optimistic. We are only at about 80 percent industrial capacity, and I think we still have a ways to go before we see that full employment unemployment rate pressure set in. I don't know how far that is because I have no idea what the full employment unemployment rate really is. But it's hard to match up 80 percent industrial capacity with 6.7 percent unemployment and say that we are there. It just doesn't look like it to me, compared to anything I have seen in the past.
description: Current unemployment rate of 6.7% with 80% capacity utilization suggests significant labor market slack remains before reaching full employment pressure
explanation: The assessment that significant slack remains in the labor market suggests monetary policy can remain accommodative without triggering wage-price pressures associated with full employment

quotation: Labor shortages continue to be the main concern of virtually all businesses in the District. The unemployment rate for our five states dropped /2 percentage point in April to an average of 3.3 percent and remained near that level in May.
description: Labor markets are very tight with widespread shortages across businesses
explanation: Extremely low unemployment at 3.3% and widespread labor shortages indicate an overheating labor market that creates inflationary wage pressures, supporting tighter monetary policy

quotation: The Labor Department tells us that there are still 6 million people who are not working. Fortunately, they do not live in my District, but I would like to see a lot more of those people find jobs. Most of the metropolitan areas in my District have unemployment rates of around 4 percent or lower, and this has been the case for a couple of years.
description: Preference for more people to find employment, noting 6 million still unemployed
explanation: Explicit preference for lower unemployment supports accommodative policy to promote job creation

quotation: I think that the unemployment rate probably understates how weak labor markets are. The way I think about that is, suppose I told you the unemployment rate was 7.7 percent and asked you to guess, based on history, what part-time employment is, what labor force participation is, what wage growth is, et cetera. I think you would give stronger numbers than are actually the case.
description: Labor market conditions are weaker than the unemployment rate suggests
explanation: Assessment that labor market is weaker than headline unemployment rate indicates supports more aggressive accommodative policy to address hidden slack.

quotation: Labor compensation growth remains anemic. Indeed, my business contacts report no sign of labor cost pressures outside of health and unemployment insurance. The economy's substantial slack will continue to weigh on inflation, and the recent appreciation of the dollar should put some further downward pressure on prices.
description: Assessment of weak labor market conditions with anemic compensation growth
explanation: Weak labor compensation growth and substantial economic slack indicate continued need for accommodative policy to strengthen labor market conditions.

quotation: Overall, the attacks ensured that nearly every District state would experience the national recession. Many states had continued to expand well into the summer of last year, especially those without a large IT presence. But widespread employment losses in the District during the fourth quarter eliminated any advantages that states had accumulated from their delayed entry into the recession.
description: September 11 attacks caused employment losses to spread to all District states
explanation: The causal role of September 11 in spreading employment losses to previously resilient states indicates a significant negative shock requiring accommodative policy to support broad-based recovery

quotation: On unemployment, we continue to forecast steady improvement to 7.1 percent by the end of 2013 and 6.3 percent by the end of 2014.
description: Forecast of steady unemployment improvement to 7.1% by end-2013 and 6.3% by end-2014
explanation: Gradual unemployment improvement suggests continued need for accommodation to support the recovery, though potentially allows for eventual policy normalization

quotation: The rate of job growth also remains below the national rate, but it finally has been sufficient to bring the region back to its pre-recession employment levels.
description: Job growth has been sufficient to restore regional employment to pre-recession levels
explanation: Full employment recovery to pre-recession levels indicates economic strength and labor market tightness that typically supports a more restrictive monetary policy approach

quotation: At this point, the 12-month change in total compensation growth in the ECI has remained virtually unchanged at around 3 percent for five quarters. I would just remind you that standard economic theory suggests that both firms and workers going to the bargaining table ought to be concerned with and ought to be bargaining over total compensation, not wages and salaries alone.
description: Total compensation growth has remained stable despite wage fluctuations, reflecting standard bargaining theory
explanation: Points to stable total compensation growth as evidence that labor cost pressures may not be building, supporting a more accommodative policy stance

quotation: we're pushing down our unemployment rate projections slightly
description: Unemployment rate projections are being revised downward for 2018 and 2019
explanation: Lower projected unemployment rates indicate a tightening labor market that supports more restrictive monetary policy to maintain economic balance

quotation: National economic activity is much stronger than earlier forecasts anticipated. Employment grew twice as fast as the labor force from January to October.
description: Employment growth has significantly exceeded forecasts, indicating stronger than expected labor market conditions
explanation: Stronger than expected employment growth suggests the economy may be overheating and could lead to inflationary pressures, warranting tighter monetary policy

quotation: Personal saving rates are estimated to be in the negative range, labor costs are rising, and labor demand remains very strong.
description: Strong labor demand and rising labor costs
explanation: Very strong labor demand and rising labor costs indicate overheating in the labor market, supporting restrictive monetary policy to moderate demand pressures.

quotation: In light of the recent rebound in consumer spending, the ongoing recovery in the housing market, and the improvement in global financial and economic conditions, the odds seem reasonably good to me that overall activity will expand at a moderate pace in coming quarters, and if so, we should expect to see a pickup in employment growth relatively soon.
description: Expected pickup in employment growth based on improving economic conditions
explanation: Expected employment growth pickup would support eventual monetary policy tightening as conditions improve.

quotation: Well, at this point, inflation is running well below our 2 percent objective. So, in pushing aggregate demand to try to bring them back into the labor force and into jobs, it seems to me that we currently face no tradeoff in terms of our dual mandate.
description: Current conditions allow helping long-term unemployed without creating inflation tradeoff
explanation: With inflation below target, stimulating demand to help long-term unemployed aligns with both employment and price stability objectives, strongly supporting continued accommodation.

quotation: This reference suggests that purchases will be zero at the time that the 7 percent level of unemployment is crossed. Given the recent behavior of unemployment, I see this as quite reckless for the Committee. Unemployment could easily cross 7 percent very soon, and we are currently, as a Committee, in no position to be at zero purchases that quickly.
description: Warning against ending asset purchases too quickly when unemployment reaches 7%
explanation: Argues that ending accommodation too abruptly when unemployment reaches threshold levels would be premature and risky, supporting continued accommodative policy even as unemployment improves

quotation: When we talk to business people about wage pressures, they give some indication that they're paying "above normal" to retain workers. But the definition of "normal" is moving higher. So we're continually seeing an increase in the so-called normal rate that gives me some pause.
description: Concerning upward drift in normal wage levels
explanation: The speaker expresses concern about structural shifts in wage expectations, with tight labor markets causing an upward drift in what's considered normal wages, supporting restrictive policy to prevent wage-price spirals.

quotation: The view across my contacts more broadly was that labor markets were tightening throughout the employment spectrum, and there were a few more reports this time of increases in compensation: wage gains, bonuses, increased profit sharing, and more generous benefits.
description: Labor markets are tightening across the employment spectrum with increasing compensation
explanation: Broad-based labor market tightening with rising compensation indicates building wage pressures that could fuel inflation, supporting the need for higher interest rates

quotation: Weak wage growth and strong productivity growth in the third quarter combined to deflate unit labor costs at an annual rate of about 6 percent. We probably won't see anything like that kind of decline in the current quarter, but the Board staff is projecting a further small decline, and it could be larger than they have forecast. From my standpoint there is just no way to get around the fact that this kind of unit labor cost performance constitutes a moderate disinflation risk in the outlook, at least for now.
description: Weak wage growth contributes to disinflation risk through unit labor cost deflation
explanation: The speaker identifies weak wage growth as a key factor causing unit labor cost deflation and creating disinflation risk. This employment-related weakness in wage growth supports accommodative policy to prevent further disinflation and support stronger labor market conditions.

quotation: The resolution of fiscal uncertainty could unleash pent-up demand on the part of businesses and, possibly, households.
description: Resolving fiscal uncertainty could unleash pent-up demand for hiring
explanation: Potential for employment improvement if uncertainties resolve supports maintaining accommodative policy to help realize this upside potential.

quotation: Indeed, the bulk of the job cuts during the fourth quarter occurred outside the IT industry —in sectors such as transportation, retail trade, and travel-related services—and they were spread across District states.
description: Fourth quarter job cuts were concentrated outside IT industry and spread across multiple sectors
explanation: Widespread job losses across multiple sectors indicates broad-based economic weakness that supports accommodative monetary policy to stimulate recovery across the economy

quotation: Output growing at its potential rate, unemployment essentially unchanging, and inflation expected to hit 2 percent sounds like a steady state.
description: Characterization of current economic state as steady state with unemployment essentially unchanging
explanation: Description of steady state with stable unemployment suggests no need for policy changes, supporting maintenance of current accommodative policy stance

quotation: In the labor market, Friday's labor market report was better than expected, but conditions in the job market remain generally sluggish. The loss of UI benefits may be one reason for lower unemployment, as people are leaving the labor force. Hiring is still weak, as shown by the JOLTS data, and there is still some evidence of a shift in the Beveridge curve.
description: Current labor market conditions remain sluggish with weak hiring despite recent unemployment decline
explanation: Weak labor market conditions with sluggish hiring and labor force exit driving unemployment decline support continued monetary accommodation to stimulate employment growth.

quotation: There was also a lot of interesting discussion about wage growth, which most of you see as quite low with very little indication of acceleration. That seems consistent with substantial remaining slack
description: Low wage growth indicates substantial remaining labor market slack
explanation: Weak wage growth signals that labor market slack remains substantial, justifying continued monetary accommodation to further reduce unemployment.

quotation: Even with that, growth was still a percentage point lower than potential and not strong enough to generate job growth.
description: Economic growth is insufficient to generate job growth
explanation: The relationship between below-potential growth and lack of job creation indicates need for more stimulative monetary policy

quotation: You take some account of the positive incoming financial market data but recognize that they cannot mask the weak incomes and the slow trajectory for improvement in labor markets.
description: Current labor markets are weak with slow trajectory for improvement
explanation: The speaker's assessment of weak current labor market conditions with slow improvement supports maintaining accommodative monetary policy to help employment recovery.

quotation: We heard for the most part continuing reluctance to hire permanent employees.
description: Firms show continuing reluctance to hire permanent employees
explanation: Reluctance to hire permanent employees indicates weak employment conditions that warrant accommodative policy to encourage job creation

quotation: The economy is operating far below maximum sustainable employment, and inflation is undesirably low—conditions that are likely to persist for several years.
description: Assessment that economy is operating far below maximum sustainable employment
explanation: The large gap between current employment and maximum sustainable employment, expected to persist for years, strongly supports continued accommodative monetary policy.

quotation: Mr. Chairman, employment in the Twelfth District continued to contract in late November and December, as firms in nearly every sector and in most District states shed jobs.
description: Employment in the Twelfth District continued to contract broadly across sectors and states in late 2001
explanation: Continued employment contraction indicates economic weakness that supports maintaining or implementing accommodative monetary policy to stimulate economic recovery

quotation: And while the unemployment rate in May fell to 4.7 percent, this reduction reflected another large decline in labor force participation, as many of you noted. Indeed, the rise in labor force participation that we had seen since last summer has been largely reversed in the past two months. This development suggests that recovery along that dimension has been much more limited than I had thought.
description: Labor force participation decline suggests labor market recovery has been more limited than expected
explanation: Limited labor market recovery with declining participation suggests continued need for accommodative policy support.

quotation: We've assumed a little more productivity growth and a lot less job creation in comparison to the Greenbook.
description: Forecast assumes less job creation compared to Greenbook baseline
explanation: Forecasting significantly less job creation than the baseline suggests weaker employment recovery that would warrant continued accommodative monetary policy

quotation: With economic growth being only modest to moderate, the unemployment rate will tick down over the next year or two.
description: Unemployment rate will decline only gradually over the next year or two due to modest economic growth
explanation: Forecast of slow unemployment improvement suggests continued need for accommodative monetary policy to support faster employment recovery

quotation: Earlier Greenbooks also had predicted that employment would finally begin to grow, and it has, if less robustly than we might have hoped.
description: Employment growth has begun but is disappointingly weak relative to expectations
explanation: The speaker's disappointment with the pace of employment growth ("less robustly than we might have hoped") suggests that current employment performance is below desired levels, supporting continued accommodative policy to strengthen job growth.

quotation: Prior to the attacks, District job losses generally were limited to the manufacturing and IT service sectors and were concentrated in IT-dependent geographic areas such as Phoenix, Portland, and the San Francisco Bay area. Following the attacks, job cuts were much more far-reaching, with employment in states and sectors that had been holding up earlier in the year contracting at a rapid pace.
description: September 11 attacks caused employment cuts to become more widespread beyond initial IT sector concentration
explanation: The causal impact of September 11 in broadening employment losses indicates a significant negative shock requiring accommodative policy response to support economic recovery

quotation: The prospect of subpar growth is likely to make the labor market recovery even more agonizingly slow that I previously expected. I now anticipate that the unemployment rate will end this year at about 9½ percent, declining only to 8½ percent at the end of 2011 and will take a couple of additional years to return to full employment.
description: Forecast of slow labor market recovery with unemployment remaining elevated for extended period
explanation: The forecast of persistently high unemployment and slow recovery suggests need for continued monetary accommodation to support employment recovery toward full employment levels.

quotation: The end of the extended unemployment compensation benefits at the end of last year essentially led to a significant expansion in the effective supply of labor, as people basically had to start really looking for work. This meant that the ability to hire someone at a given wage increased, as there was a larger effective pool of potential employees available.
description: Ending extended unemployment benefits expanded effective labor supply, explaining recent employment dynamics
explanation: This explanation suggests the labor market is less tight than it appears, reducing pressure for restrictive monetary policy

quotation: The Seventh District economy continues to expand at a moderate pace, with tight labor markets increasingly being cited as a factor constraining growth.
description: Tight labor markets are constraining economic growth
explanation: The speaker identifies tight labor markets as a constraint on growth, suggesting the economy may be overheating and requiring monetary policy tightening to restore balance.

quotation: A similar slowing was reported on the hiring front. For instance, Kelly and Manpower experienced softer demand for temporary workers, but again this was not characterized as a general pullback in hiring.
description: Current slowing in hiring activity based on district contacts
explanation: The slowing in hiring and softer demand for temporary workers indicates labor market weakness, which reduces inflationary pressures and supports the case for lower interest rates to stimulate economic activity.

quotation: In light of the May payroll data and the downward revision to payrolls in April, the main question we will need to answer in July is whether recent data may be a result of the start of a significant slowdown in employment growth or, rather, reflect the month-to-month noise that is likely to appear in any macroeconomic time series.
description: Uncertainty about whether recent employment data represents significant slowdown versus temporary noise
explanation: This uncertainty about the nature of employment weakness suggests caution in monetary policy tightening until the situation becomes clearer

quotation: One of our directors, who for months reported that his large national retailing firm had not had to raise wages to get workers, has for the first time reported labor shortages and higher labor costs.
description: Labor shortages are beginning to drive up labor costs
explanation: The emergence of labor cost pressures due to shortages represents a shift toward wage inflation that would warrant restrictive monetary policy to prevent broader inflationary pressures

quotation: On that score, I'd emphasize that we're close to our full employment objective, that the underlying pace of inflation is not far from 2 percent, and that our best guess at the value of the equilibrium real federal funds rate is near but above zero.
description: Economy is close to the full employment objective
explanation: Being close to the full employment objective suggests that further accommodation may not be necessary and gradual normalization could be appropriate

quotation: Household spending should be well supported over the near term by solid job gains and a saving rate that is higher than what one would expect on the basis of the level of net worth relative to income.
description: Solid job gains are supporting consumer spending in the near term
explanation: Strong employment supporting consumer spending indicates economic strength that could warrant tighter monetary policy

quotation: But there will be a great deal of discussion about them as well as about the bankruptcy or the ceasing of business by the implement dealers, the grain dealers, and others that have been very important to the Main Street merchant in these small agricultural towns. And the impact is going to be very great.
description: Expected significant negative employment impact from agricultural distress spreading to related businesses and small towns
explanation: Forecasted widespread business failures and employment losses in agricultural-dependent communities suggest need for accommodative policy to mitigate economic distress

quotation: In the business sector, businesses continued to see heightened uncertainty, which leads them to reduce investment and rely on part-time workers.
description: Business uncertainty leads to reduced investment and reliance on part-time workers
explanation: Uncertainty constraining business hiring and leading to part-time employment suggests need for accommodative policy to support full-time job creation.

quotation: Our view emphasizes a forecast that places real GDP growth at about 2 percent over the forecast horizon, with inflation also at about 2 percent. Unlike the Tealbook, we do not regard 2 percent real GDP growth as being meaningfully above trend. Consequently, we also expect relatively little change in the unemployment rate over the forecast horizon. We think end-of­ year unemployment rates will remain centered on 4.7 percent.
description: Forecast that unemployment rate will remain stable at 4.7% over the forecast horizon due to GDP growth being at trend rather than above trend
explanation: Stable unemployment forecast suggests no labor market overheating that would require restrictive policy, supporting maintenance of current accommodative stance

quotation: Weak real disposable incomes coming from weak labor markets and the problems that small businesses will no doubt confront in the next 18 months, as highlighted by Governor Kohn, suggest to me that we run the risk of more-persistent weakness on the income side than the upside improvements in balance sheets and household net worth.
description: Weak labor markets will persist for 18 months and cause weak disposable incomes
explanation: The forecast of persistent labor market weakness over 18 months and the causal link to weak incomes supports accommodative policy to address employment challenges and their economic consequences.

quotation: Now, you may plug in a negative productivity number. That's one way of reconciling it. Maybe the November and December employment data will get revised down. I guess that's another way of reconciling it.
description: Uncertainty about employment strength due to potential data revisions or productivity explanations
explanation: The suggestion that employment strength might be overstated due to potential downward revisions implies less underlying economic strength than initially apparent, supporting a more cautious approach to policy tightening

quotation: It suggests that maybe the unemployment rate overstates the tightness of the labor market by about ½ percentage point. In other words, if you could get U-6 down to where you'd expect it to be relative to U-3, you might get about ½ percent of additional hours worked. So it points in the right direction of saying that you have some extra labor market slack, but it's not a huge increment of slack, in my opinion.
description: Labor market has some additional slack but not a huge increment
explanation: Finding limited remaining labor market slack suggests the economy is approaching full employment, supporting the case for less accommodative monetary policy

quotation: Job growth has remained strong in Oregon and has picked up further from already high rates in Nevada, Utah, and Idaho, leaving those four states the fastest growing in the nation.
description: Strong job growth in western states indicates economic acceleration requiring policy response
explanation: Strong job growth across multiple states suggests the economy is accelerating and may be overheating, supporting the need for tighter monetary policy to prevent inflationary pressures.

quotation: For most of 2005, however, it has seemed that the region might be gaining a bit—with employment growing at a pace only slightly behind that of the nation, signs of life in manufacturing, and strong residential real estate markets.
description: New England employment is growing at a pace only slightly behind the nation, showing modest regional improvement
explanation: Modest employment growth that still lags the nation suggests continued economic slack and room for accommodation to support stronger job creation

quotation: With oil prices hovering in the $12 range and not expected to pick up appreciably in the near future, consolidations and layoffs in the energy sector will likely continue for quite some time.
description: Expected continued layoffs in energy sector due to low oil prices
explanation: Forecasted layoffs in the energy sector suggest employment weakness in this region, which would support more accommodative monetary policy to offset negative employment effects

quotation: Data for California indicate that average hours worked per week in the manufacturing sector as a whole rose in December, hitting the highest level since 2000.
description: Manufacturing hours worked increased in December to highest level since 2000
explanation: While this shows some improvement in employment conditions, it represents early signs of recovery that support maintaining current accommodative policy rather than tightening prematurely

quotation: The underlying narrative is that the effects of declining slack and disappointing productivity are more or less offsetting.
description: Belief that declining labor market slack and disappointing productivity are offsetting each other in wage determination
explanation: The offsetting effects suggest that despite declining slack, wage pressures remain muted, supporting continued accommodative policy to allow further labor market healing without triggering excessive inflation.

quotation: First, with regard to our District, like President Hoenig's, our two Districts, I believe, are the only ones that had positive employment growth last year. In the Eleventh District, we created 192,400 jobs, according to our adjusted data, all in the private sector. That machine has stopped; in fact, we would have a straight line downward if we were to chart it.
description: The Eleventh District had strong employment growth in the previous year but this positive trend has completely stopped
explanation: The sharp reversal from strong job creation to declining employment indicates deteriorating labor market conditions that would support more accommodative monetary policy to stimulate economic activity and employment.

quotation: As Bill Wascher emphasized, long-term unemployment has now risen from its pre-recession level of about 1 percent to over 4 percent, and, as of May, 46 percent of the unemployed had been without a job for at least 27 weeks. This is an extremely disconcerting situation, one that translates into tremendous hardship for families and that has potentially serious adverse long- term consequences.
description: Assessment of severe long-term unemployment situation with adverse consequences
explanation: The severe deterioration in long-term unemployment and its serious consequences highlight the urgent need for accommodative policy to address employment problems.

quotation: Retailers continue to describe consumers as worried about job security and cautious in their spending.
description: Job security concerns are affecting consumer spending
explanation: Job insecurity is constraining consumer spending, creating a feedback loop that justifies accommodative policy to support both employment and economic growth

quotation: we're at a very tight labor market, but we actually have plenty of manufacturing capacity... So there's a real asymmetry between the tightness of the labor market and the tightness of manufacturing capacity
description: Current labor market exhibits significant tightness despite slack in manufacturing capacity
explanation: Emphasis on labor market tightness as the binding constraint supports restrictive policy despite manufacturing slack

quotation: That pattern was reversed in the course of 1996, with employment growth slowing but the unemployment rate also falling. The latter fell to slightly below the national average, its lowest level in fifteen years.
description: Employment growth slowed but unemployment fell to 15-year lows in the district during 1996
explanation: Unemployment at 15-year lows suggests very tight labor market conditions that could lead to wage pressures and inflation, supporting tighter monetary policy

quotation: Although I do expect some slowing in growth next year, it would not be enough to prevent the economy from stretching beyond the full utilization of its resources.
description: Economy expected to operate beyond full employment capacity despite policy tightening
explanation: The forecast that the economy will operate beyond full resource utilization implies employment will exceed sustainable levels, creating inflationary pressures that justify restrictive monetary policy.

quotation: My final 'if' concerned the relationship between faster compensation growth and product price inflation and whether we should automatically assume that the translation there will be one-for-one. The counter argument is that for the last several years product price increases have outstripped increases in unit labor costs and that has resulted in widening markups, unusually strong earnings growth, and a rise in the profit share.
description: Recent compensation growth may not translate to higher inflation due to widening profit margins
explanation: Suggests that even if compensation growth increases, it may not lead to higher inflation because profit margins could absorb the cost increases, reducing the need for preemptive policy tightening

quotation: What did we see? We saw payrolls growing rapidly relative to the underlying growth base. It sort of fits what we actually saw in terms of the economic data. In other words, some of the increase in job vacancies reflects an increase in demand responding to the increase in effective supply.
description: Rapid payroll growth reflects supply-driven rather than demand-driven labor market dynamics
explanation: Interpreting rapid payroll growth as supply-driven suggests less labor market tightness and wage pressure than demand-driven growth would imply

quotation: Domestic demand has not slowed appreciably, and wage and price data show some deterioration.
description: Wage pressures are deteriorating alongside other price pressures
explanation: Deteriorating wage and price data indicate building inflationary pressures that warrant restrictive monetary policy to maintain price stability

quotation: We often hear that worker scarcity is a problem, that employers can't find workers with the skills that they need. And then usually I turn around and ask them, "Okay. Are you raising wages?" "No. We're not in a position to do that." So I take these anecdotes with a grain of salt. Until we see them raising wages, I don't take much information from them.
description: Skepticism about labor shortage claims due to lack of corresponding wage increases
explanation: Doubting true labor scarcity suggests the labor market is less tight than anecdotal reports indicate, implying room for further employment gains without inflationary pressure, supporting accommodative policy

quotation: Beyond this, the demand for labor nationally appears to be outstripping the sustainable supply currently by a factor of maybe 2 or 3.
description: National labor demand is outstripping sustainable supply by a factor of 2 or 3
explanation: Labor demand significantly exceeding sustainable supply indicates the economy is operating well above potential, creating substantial upside risks to inflation and warranting restrictive monetary policy.

quotation: I see several positives with respect to housing, including the relatively low level of housing starts relative to employment growth and the easing of lending standards for residential mortgages
description: Housing starts are relatively low compared to employment growth, indicating economic strength
explanation: Employment growth outpacing housing starts suggests robust labor market conditions that support economic expansion and potentially restrictive policy

quotation: That rate of growth should also mean continued job creation at a pace that will materially reduce labor market slack.
description: Forecast that continued growth will generate job creation sufficient to materially reduce labor market slack
explanation: Continued job creation that materially reduces slack suggests the economy is moving toward full employment, supporting the case for less accommodative monetary policy to prevent overheating.

quotation: We saw pretty dramatic numbers announced one day or two days ago, and I think that is intensifying, not lessening.
description: Employment cuts are intensifying rather than moderating
explanation: The intensification of job cuts indicates worsening employment conditions that would support more accommodative monetary policy to help arrest the deteriorating labor market situation.

quotation: Of course, indicators of business investment outside the energy sector had remained puzzlingly soft, but with firms still willing to expand their workforces, I was optimistic that capital spending would gradually pick up in response to stronger household spending and foreign growth.
description: Firms' willingness to expand workforces despite soft business investment suggests optimism for capital spending recovery
explanation: Firms expanding workforces indicates economic strength and confidence, supporting the case for gradual policy tightening.

quotation: We now have had three years during which economic growth has been faster than most people's estimate of potential and the unemployment rate has been below most people's estimate of NAIRU.
description: Unemployment has been below NAIRU estimates for three years
explanation: Sustained unemployment below NAIRU estimates suggests the labor market has been operating beyond sustainable levels, which typically supports restrictive monetary policy to prevent inflationary pressures

quotation: in view of the strength of the economy, the tightness of the labor market, and buoyant financial market conditions—the risk, to me, seems to be on the side of a more rapid pace of rate hikes than that
description: Tightness of labor market suggests risk of needing faster pace of rate increases
explanation: Labor market tightness is explicitly cited as supporting potentially faster rate increases than currently projected

quotation: Still, the main message is that the unemployment rate is about to move still further below NAIRU and as a result inflation pressures are likely to build over the forecast horizon.
description: Unemployment moving further below NAIRU will build inflation pressures
explanation: Unemployment declining further below NAIRU will generate inflation pressures, indicating need for restrictive policy to prevent this outcome or address its consequences.

quotation: The incoming data on consumer and business spending and the labor market also suggest the economy is firing on all cylinders and has plenty of momentum heading into this year.
description: Strong labor market data indicates the economy has significant momentum
explanation: Strong labor market performance as part of broad economic strength suggests the economy may be overheating, warranting restrictive monetary policy to prevent excessive inflation

quotation: There are labor shortages in a few sectors and a lack of qualified workers in some cases, but there is little evidence of wage pressures, broadly speaking.
description: Limited wage pressures despite some labor shortages indicate continued labor market slack
explanation: Absence of broad wage pressures despite sectoral shortages suggests overall labor market slack remains, supporting continued accommodation.

quotation: Finally, the price data had come in about as I expected, consistent with my forecast that inflation would move up to 2 percent over the next two years or so, conditional on further labor market improvement, reasonably well-anchored inflation expectations, and roughly stable prices for oil and non-energy imports.
description: Labor market improvement is a key condition for inflation reaching the 2% target
explanation: Expected labor market improvement supporting inflation reaching target would justify gradual monetary policy tightening.

quotation: I don't think we are all that far away from it--as it would seem, from the 7 percent unemployment figure, we think that full employment is somewhere between 5.5 and 6 percent.
description: Full employment is estimated at 5.5-6% unemployment, with current unemployment at 7%
explanation: With unemployment only 1-1.5 percentage points above the full employment level, the economy is close to full employment, suggesting less need for accommodative policy.

quotation: Recent economic data, the seemingly stronger health of the labor markets, and the expected flattening out of oil prices are all good news.
description: Recent data shows stronger health of labor markets
explanation: Stronger labor market health suggests the economy is improving and may have less need for accommodative policy, supporting a move toward more restrictive policy

quotation: The Committee is going to be discussing enhancing forward guidance in March, it sounds like, because there's a good chance that we'll pass through the unemployment threshold in the very near future.
description: Unemployment rate will likely pass through the 6.5% threshold in the near future
explanation: Crossing the unemployment threshold would trigger reconsideration of forward guidance and potentially signal conditions are improving enough to consider less accommodative policy

quotation: While skills training capability is improving in the United States at high schools and at junior colleges, we believe it is not nearly keeping up with the need to retrain and train members of the workforce.
description: Skills training capacity insufficient to meet workforce retraining needs
explanation: Inadequate skills training suggests structural unemployment challenges as technology displaces workers, potentially requiring accommodative policy to support employment during the transition.

quotation: Adjusting for the effects of the Verizon strike, payrolls increased only 73,000 in May, and the figures for March and April were marked down a total of 85,000. As a consequence, the average increase over the past three months, while admittedly somewhat better than the May figure, was just 125,000 per month, representing a marked and abrupt slowdown in employment growth whether measured relative to average monthly gains of 220,000 over the preceding three months or the 230,000 per month pace seen last year.
description: Employment growth showed marked and abrupt slowdown in spring 2016
explanation: Sharp employment slowdown indicates economic weakness that warrants accommodative monetary policy stance.

quotation: Expected growth is going to be sufficient to drive the unemployment rate, we believe, below 4 percent this year and well below that in the medium term... With the unemployment rate at 4.1 percent and with expectations of solid near-term real GDP growth, I think we're on a course that will take us well past full employment over the next year and in the medium term
description: National unemployment expected to fall well below 4 percent and past full employment
explanation: Forecasting unemployment well below 4% and past full employment suggests potential overheating and inflationary pressures, warranting preemptive tightening of monetary policy

quotation: The Bureau of Labor Statistics' announcement of a pending major upward revision in payroll employment means that the help that we thought we would get from productivity is much lower, causing an upward revision in the trend of labor costs.
description: Upward revisions to payroll employment reduce productivity gains and increase labor cost pressures
explanation: Higher labor costs due to employment data revisions create inflationary pressures that require restrictive monetary policy to contain.

quotation: Sixth, the rate of unemployment in our view is below the NAIRU, which we think is 6 percent, give or take 0.1. We could be wrong. Since unemployment is now below 6 percent and the CPI is rather well behaved, the question could be asked, is God kinder and has the NAIRU become lower? We don't think so.
description: Unemployment rate is currently below NAIRU of 6 percent
explanation: With unemployment below the natural rate, inflationary pressures are likely to build, requiring tighter monetary policy to bring unemployment back toward its natural level.

quotation: The District's unemployment rate edged down to about 3.4 percent in August and we continue to have tight labor markets.
description: Very low unemployment rate and continued tight labor markets
explanation: Extremely low unemployment and tight labor markets indicate potential inflationary pressures from labor shortages, supporting restrictive monetary policy.

quotation: And because of my view about the lack of robust strength in the economy as compared to the Greenbook forecast, I would think that unemployment will not be as low as in the Greenbook.
description: Unemployment is expected to remain higher than staff forecasts due to weaker economic growth prospects
explanation: If unemployment is expected to remain higher due to weaker growth, this suggests the economy may need more accommodative monetary policy to support employment and economic expansion

quotation: With some slack remaining in the economy and with inflation below target, we need above-trend growth to continue the healing process.
description: Assessment that labor market slack remains and requires above-trend growth for continued healing
explanation: Remaining labor market slack justifies maintaining accommodative policy to support above-trend growth needed for continued labor market healing and progress toward full employment.

quotation: But when I looked at their employment numbers, the last four or five months of 1986 showed pretty quiet employment in manufacturing.
description: Manufacturing employment showed weakness in late 1986 despite export strength
explanation: Weak manufacturing employment suggests economic softness that could warrant accommodative monetary policy to support growth

quotation: I'd like to see further confirmation of employment growth, but business investment, consumer spending, homebuilding, and motor vehicle production all indicate that the first part of 2005 could be even a little stronger than we anticipate, assuming the November trade deficit was a bit of an anomaly.
description: Desires further confirmation of employment growth but sees positive economic outlook
explanation: While wanting more employment confirmation, the overall positive economic outlook and expectation of stronger growth supports continued gradual policy normalization

quotation: The biggest risk in my mind, though, remains the employment trend, which has been very sturdy relative to the pace of economic growth. If that trend stays intact over the next few months—I'm going to speak on the monetary policy part here—then I think the case for monetary policy liftoff will be quite compelling.
description: Continued sturdy employment trends would make a compelling case for monetary policy liftoff
explanation: Strong employment trends directly support the case for raising interest rates (policy liftoff)

quotation: For the Eleventh District, we have been right at the top of the Districts in terms of maintenance of employment levels. As a matter of fact, we were probably number one until a couple of months ago; I believe about a month ago the Kansas City District overtook us.
description: The Eleventh District had strong employment performance until recently when it began to weaken relative to other districts
explanation: The weakening of previously strong employment performance suggests economic deterioration that would warrant accommodative monetary policy to support employment levels

quotation: Our largest industry in terms of employment, our medical industry, is suffering in terms of foreigners who come to be repaired in Houston, Dallas, and elsewhere.
description: The medical industry, a major employer, is suffering from reduced foreign patients
explanation: Weakness in the largest employment sector indicates significant labor market stress that would support more accommodative monetary policy to help stabilize employment conditions.

quotation: Employment in most parts of the District is up and unemployment is down; even in those places where we still have rather high unemployment rates, they are down from their earlier double-digit rates.
description: Current employment conditions in the Atlanta District are strong with rising employment and declining unemployment rates
explanation: Strong current employment conditions suggest the economy may be heating up, which would support tighter monetary policy to prevent overheating and inflationary pressures

quotation: In those simulations, a combination of tight labor markets and dissipation and reversal of some of the forces that recently have been restraining inflation finally begin to put upward pressure on inflation into 1999 and beyond.
description: Tight labor markets will eventually cause upward inflation pressure in 1999 and beyond
explanation: The longer-term causal relationship between tight labor markets and inflation suggests restrictive policy will be needed to prevent inflation from rising

quotation: District employers shed nearly three times more jobs in the fourth quarter than they had in the previous two quarters combined. And the Districtwide unemployment rate jumped ¾ percentage point from September to December, the largest three-month increase since the BLS started recording individual state data.
description: Employment losses accelerated dramatically in Q4 with unprecedented unemployment rate increases
explanation: The severe acceleration in job losses and historic unemployment rate increases indicate acute economic distress requiring strong accommodative policy response

quotation: The November employment report was disappointing, but taken in the context of the last several months of job growth and other data, I have become more confident that the economy has found solid footing.
description: Despite disappointing November employment report, recent job growth and other data support confidence in solid economic footing
explanation: The speaker's confidence in economic conditions despite disappointing employment data suggests the economy is fundamentally sound, supporting continued gradual monetary tightening rather than accommodation

quotation: In the September SEP, we had median expectations regarding second-half real GDP growth of 2 percent and unemployment at 5 percent. Those will be met, hypothetically.
description: Expectation that unemployment target of 5 percent will be met, supporting previous policy guidance
explanation: Meeting the unemployment target supports the case for policy normalization as previously communicated, suggesting conditions for less accommodative policy are being achieved.

quotation: Certainly, we are seeing payroll growth move up. The three-month averages of total and private payroll gains are now around 180,000 a month, whereas at the time of the February report, they were running around 130,000.
description: Payroll growth has accelerated significantly from earlier in the year
explanation: Accelerating job creation indicates strengthening labor market conditions that support reducing monetary accommodation.

quotation: Whatever the referendum decision on British membership in the EU, we will also have to appraise the recent weakening in payroll data.
description: Recent weakening in payroll data requires careful appraisal and suggests delaying interest rate increases
explanation: Weakening employment data creates uncertainty that argues for maintaining current accommodative policy stance rather than raising rates

quotation: In recent contacts with business executives and directors in the Eighth District, the consensus was that wage pressures are building, especially for unskilled workers and construction workers. I have been hearing these reports and have mentioned them here for some time, but I'm hearing more and more reports of actual increases in wages.
description: Wage pressures are building across different worker categories based on business contacts
explanation: Widespread and intensifying wage pressures across worker categories indicate broad-based labor market tightness that could fuel inflation, supporting restrictive monetary policy

quotation: Sooner or later, the tight labor markets will probably spill over into higher prices, but that prospect seemed imminent a year or more ago.
description: Tight labor markets will eventually lead to higher prices despite not having done so yet
explanation: Expectation that tight labor markets will eventually cause inflation supports preemptive restrictive policy, even though the timing has been longer than expected

quotation: On the other side, I won't belabor the points on the energy, mining, and agricultural areas in which our District is very deeply involved, but all of them are flat on their backs.
description: Very weak employment conditions in energy, mining, and agricultural sectors
explanation: Severe weakness in these major employment sectors suggests need for accommodative monetary policy to support economic recovery

quotation: Second, a tighter labor market is likely to translate soon into higher compensation trends. While I know that the linkage between wages and inflation is very tenuous, I still believe that pressure on resources does matter in terms of affecting the inflation outlook.
description: Tighter labor market will lead to higher compensation and inflation pressures
explanation: Tight labor markets creating wage and inflation pressures provide justification for restrictive monetary policy to prevent overheating

quotation: Nevertheless, they still indicate that the labor market continues to tighten.
description: Labor market continues to tighten based on various indicators
explanation: Continued labor market tightening suggests ongoing reduction in slack that will likely lead to accelerating wage growth and inflationary pressures

quotation: They are aggressively cutting head count. One of the CEOs I talked to, who employs one of the largest workforces in the country, said he had three drawers. In the one drawer he plans to cut 17,000 jobs, unannounced as yet; in a drawer to the right of that, a still higher number; and in a drawer to the right of that, a still higher number. I asked about the drawers to the left, and he said, "There are none."
description: Major employers are planning massive job cuts with no plans for hiring
explanation: Massive planned job cuts with no offsetting hiring plans indicate severe employment deterioration ahead, strongly supporting accommodative monetary policy to mitigate the economic downturn and employment losses.

quotation: Employment still is fairly strong, although the unemployment rate did tick up last month and there has been some discussion about the volatility of the participation rates.
description: Employment remains fairly strong despite recent uptick in unemployment rate
explanation: Strong employment conditions suggest labor market tightness that could lead to inflationary pressures, supporting tighter monetary policy

quotation: On the other hand, one person pointed out that the economy is still in such a deep hole, with 6 million jobs less than the total number before the recession, that additional support might be needed.
description: Economy remains 6 million jobs below pre-recession levels, suggesting additional policy support may be needed
explanation: Large remaining employment gap from pre-recession levels indicates the economy still needs significant support, justifying continued accommodative monetary policy

quotation: Moreover, fuel for continued gains in consumer spending is evident in solid job gains and lower energy prices—lower energy prices that are likely to boost the growth rate of real income.
description: Solid job gains are supporting consumer spending and economic growth
explanation: Solid job gains supporting consumer spending indicates economic strength that could justify policy normalization

quotation: There are good reasons, I think, to expect inflation and expectations of inflation to remain well behaved over the next year or so, but they are all based on the variety of ways we have of assessing what is not directly observable, and that's the amount of slack in the economy. These measures are credible and reliable, but it's also wise to be cautious about how accurate they can be in an environment of expected solid growth. Excess capacity could be used faster than we expect, or we could be starting with less of it.
description: Caution about potentially underestimating capacity constraints and faster resource utilization
explanation: Concern about potentially underestimating capacity constraints and the possibility of faster-than-expected resource utilization suggests risk of tighter labor markets, supporting less accommodative policy as a precautionary measure

quotation: Second, the incoming data suggest a greater decline in housing and a somewhat weaker labor market.
description: Assessment that incoming data show a weaker labor market
explanation: The speaker's assessment of weaker labor market conditions from incoming data supports accommodative monetary policy to address economic softening and reduce the risk of further deterioration.

quotation: From these data, I conclude that, following the publication of the first estimate of 160,000 for the net payroll increase in April, we should have been more vigorous in explaining to the public that although that number was below our forecast and that of others, it was still adequate to prevent increases in unemployment, conditional on plausible behavior in the participation rate—though, of course, that is not the case for the May payroll data.
description: Mixed assessment of recent payroll data - April numbers were adequate to prevent unemployment increases, but May data more concerning
explanation: While April data was adequate, the concerning May data suggests a more cautious policy approach is warranted

quotation: For example, on the plus side: we have a fairly large producer of automobiles--I think second in the nation--and that's going full out; the high-tech and defense industry is booming; commercial construction, at least in Kansas City and Omaha, is very vigorous.
description: Strong employment conditions in certain sectors including automobiles, high-tech, defense, and commercial construction
explanation: Strong employment conditions in these sectors suggest economic strength that could warrant tighter monetary policy to prevent overheating

quotation: With the rate of expansion that is indicated--that is, a slowing in 1978 even below 5 percent--I don't see much wrong because, as time goes by, we are getting closer to the full-employment ceiling and, even sooner probably, to the manufacturing capacity ceiling, the capital stock ceiling.
description: Economy is approaching the full-employment ceiling
explanation: As the economy approaches full employment, there is less need for accommodative monetary policy and more risk of overheating, supporting a more restrictive stance.

quotation: The trends in automation, as we've said many times, are reducing the pricing power of various types of businesses, causing them to invest more in technology in order to replace people and much more aggressively seek scale economies through merger activity.
description: Automation trends causing businesses to invest in technology to replace people
explanation: Automation reducing both employment and pricing power suggests disinflationary pressures and potential future labor market slack, supporting more accommodative monetary policy to maintain full employment.

quotation: Many companies that we speak with are also citing explicit plans to use investment and automation to replace workers and drive down the size of their workforce relative to output.
description: Companies explicitly planning to use automation to replace workers and reduce workforce size
explanation: Planned automation to reduce employment suggests future labor market slack and potential deflationary pressures from reduced labor demand, supporting accommodative monetary policy.

quotation: Even now, various measures of wage pressures are sending contrary signals. The better reading may be the ECI data, but the upward trend in unit labor costs should not be ignored.
description: Wage pressure measures are sending conflicting signals, but upward trend in unit labor costs should not be ignored
explanation: Rising unit labor costs represent potential inflationary pressures that warrant attention and may require more restrictive policy to prevent wage-price spiral

quotation: expects the pace of recovery to pick up over coming quarters and the unemployment rate to resume its gradual decline
description: Committee expects unemployment rate to resume gradual decline over coming quarters
explanation: The expectation of gradual rather than rapid unemployment decline suggests a measured approach to policy normalization, supporting continued accommodation until employment conditions improve more substantially

quotation: Let me start with one anecdote about housing activity in the District. I don't know how representative this is nationwide, obviously, but there are signs of slowing in both housing construction and, more dramatically, in sales recently. And this winter in the Twin Cities, several hundred unionized construction workers are not working. Last year 100 percent were.
description: Current employment weakness in construction sector due to housing market slowdown
explanation: The observation of significant construction employment weakness suggests economic softening that could warrant more accommodative monetary policy to support employment

quotation: This uncertainty in the labor market or lack of confidence among workers may well contribute to consumer spending vulnerability.
description: Labor market uncertainty may contribute to consumer spending vulnerability
explanation: Labor market uncertainty leading to weaker consumer spending suggests economic vulnerability that would support easier monetary policy

quotation: If we conclude that employment growth is slowing significantly, then, in order to judge whether we are at least maintaining the important progress we have made toward our full employment mandate, we will have to pay more attention to the number of additions to payrolls that are needed to maintain full employment. The answer depends on the trend in the labor force participation rate.
description: Need to assess payroll additions relative to full employment mandate, with the required level depending on labor force participation trends
explanation: Concern about maintaining progress toward the full employment mandate suggests a cautious approach to policy tightening, especially given the structural relationship with participation rates

quotation: In the steel sector, we are hearing that wages are expected to be up about 3-1/2 percent this year, and our contacts say that such an increase is in line with gains in productivity.
description: Steel sector wages expected to rise 3.5% in line with productivity gains
explanation: Wage increases matched by productivity gains suggest no inflationary pressure from this sector, supporting accommodative policy

quotation: Manufacturing is expanding, notably autos. Other sectors that have been doing well include oil and gas production, high-end retail, and agriculture. And some offshore employment is being brought back to the U.S.
description: Positive employment developments in manufacturing, autos, and other sectors with some reshoring
explanation: Positive employment developments across multiple sectors suggest improving labor market conditions that could support less accommodative monetary policy

quotation: the decline in payroll employment caused us to lower our near-term outlook somewhat.
description: Decline in payroll employment leading to downward revision of economic outlook
explanation: The causal relationship between declining payroll employment and a lowered economic outlook indicates labor market weakness that warrants accommodative policy to support economic growth and employment recovery.

quotation: For example, over the past 12 months average manufacturing wages have increased about 6 percent in Idaho and about 10 percent in Nevada.
description: Rapid manufacturing wage growth demonstrates overheating labor markets
explanation: Manufacturing wage increases of 6-10% annually provide concrete evidence of labor market overheating that supports the need for tighter monetary policy to contain inflationary pressures.

quotation: A second possibility is that the reported slowdown in employment growth is real but reflects a lagged response on the part of firms to the weakness in aggregate spending seen late last year and this winter. Such a slowdown would arguably be consistent with the recent weakness in non-energy-related business investment.
description: Employment slowdown could reflect lagged response to earlier economic weakness
explanation: Even if employment weakness reflects lagged effects, it still indicates current economic softness warranting policy caution.

quotation: To start off, I would consider setting the initial specification of that Taylor rule by calculating what NAIRU would have to be to make the current setting of the funds rate the Taylor rule prescription. The answer is that in the Taylor Rule with imposed coefficients, the NAIRU would have to be about 4½ percent. I think that is very much on the low side, but some might find it a plausible number.
description: NAIRU would need to be about 4½ percent to justify current policy, which is viewed as too low
explanation: The speaker's belief that a 4½ percent NAIRU is too low implies that current unemployment levels are below sustainable levels, supporting tighter monetary policy

quotation: But now we're beginning to experience a decline in employment and a rise in unemployment rates.
description: The district is currently experiencing declining employment and rising unemployment rates
explanation: Current deterioration in employment conditions supports the need for accommodative monetary policy to stimulate job growth and reduce unemployment

quotation: If you look at the growth of wages at this stage of the economic expansion and compare it to all other postwar periods, you will find that unit wage costs are relatively cheaper than they have ever been in the postwar period at this stage of the cycle. And I think that's one of the reasons why we are seeing a lot of substitution toward the employment side, despite some of the advantages to capital purchases [unintelligible], especially in the equipment area.
description: Unit wage costs are historically low for this stage of the economic cycle, driving substitution toward employment over capital investment
explanation: Historically low wage costs suggest the labor market is not overheating despite strong employment growth, supporting continued accommodative monetary policy without immediate inflationary pressure concerns

quotation: They say that in the end the difference in labor costs is about $2.00 an hour, but when the labor cost is only 30 cents per $6.00 trash can, it is irrelevant. They say that labor could be free in Guangdong province and they still could not make such products there and import them at a profit.
description: Labor costs have become so small relative to productivity that location decisions are no longer driven by wage differentials
explanation: Structural shift where labor costs become irrelevant due to efficiency gains reduces wage-driven inflation risks

quotation: Second, our forecast generally called for a slowing to trend growth just around the corner, so we waited for the spontaneous slowdown rather than imposing a policy-induced slowdown. Of course, while we waited for the slowdown, continued above-trend growth kept pushing the unemployment rate lower until we ended up at a 4¼ percent unemployment rate.
description: Past accommodative policy allowed unemployment to fall to unsustainably low levels
explanation: The assessment that past accommodation was excessive and led to unsustainably low unemployment implies the need for more restrictive policy going forward

quotation: Well, one reason is, we might conclude—based in part on the higher rates of wage increase that we've seen recently and a core PCE price inflation rate that is at about 1.5 percent—that we are close to our targets, that the inflation rate is within close reach of 2 percent, and that we are already at very near full employment.
description: Assessment that the economy is currently near full employment
explanation: Being near full employment suggests the economy may be approaching capacity constraints, which would support gradual policy normalization through rate increases

quotation: However, we have heard that Asia may be the reason for slowing in the temporary help industry.
description: Asian economic problems may be causing some employment softening in specific sectors
explanation: Slowing employment growth in some sectors due to external factors suggests reduced inflationary pressures that could support more accommodative policy

quotation: companies increasingly are seeking to improve gross margins as well as operating profit margins by investing in technology that allows them to replace people and improve productivity... Our discussions lead us to believe the effect of disruption on the U.S. workforce is significant
description: Technology-enabled disruption causing structural job displacement
explanation: Structural technological displacement of workers may reduce wage pressures despite tight labor market conditions, suggesting less need for aggressive monetary tightening

quotation: The forces that threaten to raise inflation over the forecast horizon are the prospect of a dissipation of favorable supply shocks and the expected persistence of very tight labor markets.
description: Very tight current labor markets threaten to raise inflation over the forecast horizon
explanation: The speaker identifies very tight labor markets as a key force that will threaten inflation, implying that current employment conditions are unsustainably tight and will require restrictive monetary policy to prevent inflation from rising.

quotation: I do not believe, therefore, that the decline in core inflation experienced over 1996 suggests that NAIRU is below the 5.4 percent average unemployment rate for the year. I suspect that NAIRU, at least for the near term, is near 5-1/2 percent.
description: NAIRU is estimated to be around 5.5 percent
explanation: With NAIRU at 5.5% and current unemployment below this level, the economy is operating in inflationary territory, supporting restrictive policy to bring unemployment back toward NAIRU.

quotation: I, for one, would hope that what we're seeing in the early years of this century is not indicative of future female labor force participation. Maybe there is an economic reason for why that pattern of female participation is occurring, but I have yet to see one that really strikes me as reasonable.
description: Concern that declining female labor force participation in early 2000s may represent a problematic longer-term trend
explanation: Declining female labor force participation would reduce labor supply and potentially create inflationary pressures, suggesting need for more restrictive policy to offset these supply-side constraints

quotation: My tight labor market anecdote of the month from the Eleventh District is that a competitor of Texas Instruments put up a billboard across the freeway from the Texas Instruments headquarters in Dallas. On the billboard it said, 'Why did the engineer cross the road? To get a better job.'
description: Evidence of extremely tight current labor market conditions
explanation: The anecdotal evidence of extremely tight labor markets, where companies are aggressively competing for workers, typically supports restrictive monetary policy to prevent overheating and wage-price spirals.

quotation: Mr. Chairman, while economic activity is healthy in most of the Twelfth District, weakness in California persists. Payroll employment, usually what we consider to be the most reliable short-term indicator of economic activity for a state, continues to decline.
description: Assessment that California payroll employment continues to decline despite some stabilization
explanation: Continuing employment declines in a major regional economy suggest remaining economic slack that could justify maintaining accommodative monetary policy

quotation: In filling out the June SEP, I indicated one increase in the federal funds rate for 2016 because I expected that, and I hope now that tightening labor markets will continue to push inflation toward our 2 percent target. I haven't seen the evidence of that yet.
description: Expectation that tightening labor markets will push inflation toward target, but evidence not yet seen
explanation: While expecting labor market tightening to boost inflation, the lack of current evidence suggests waiting for clearer signs before tightening policy, supporting continued accommodation

quotation: The paper's basic finding is that, under current staff assumptions regarding trend inflation, structural productivity growth, and the natural rate of unemployment, wages are not growing unusually slowly.
description: Assessment that current wage growth is stable and not unusually slow given economic conditions
explanation: Normal wage growth suggests the labor market is not generating excessive inflationary pressures, supporting a gradual approach to policy tightening rather than aggressive action.

quotation: Reports of compensation increases reached a new record high. Some 32 percent of the firms said they had raised compensation, and that is 8 percentage points higher than in any previous report. But on the other side, plans to raise compensation in 1997 fell significantly, almost to a record low.
description: Record high compensation increases reported by small businesses, with 32% raising compensation
explanation: Record high compensation increases suggest wage pressures that could lead to inflation, warranting tighter monetary policy to prevent overheating

quotation: In January we had an uptick in manufacturing employment at a 7 percent annual rate.
description: Manufacturing employment showed positive growth in January at 7% annual rate
explanation: Strong employment growth suggests economic strengthening that could reduce need for accommodative policy

quotation: The non-manufacturing economy is doing well; the unemployment rate had drifted below 4 percent, and now it's running about 3-1/2 percent.
description: Non-manufacturing sector shows very tight labor market conditions with unemployment at 3.5%
explanation: Very low unemployment rate indicates tight labor market conditions that could lead to wage pressures and inflation, suggesting need for restrictive policy

quotation: The responses indicated that, on average, about one-fourth of the tax savings is expected to go to capital spending, and about 15 percent to labor, so most is planned to be used to pay down debt, M&A, and returning funds to shareholders.
description: Corporate tax cuts are expected to provide additional stimulus to labor markets
explanation: Tax cuts directing 15% of savings to labor will add fiscal stimulus to already tight labor markets, potentially exacerbating wage pressures and supporting the case for monetary tightening

quotation: On that theory, I do think it's wise, for the time being, to look past the December employment report, the market turmoil, and other signs of weakness.
description: December employment report should be ignored due to data uncertainty and high standard errors in initial employment reports
explanation: Suggests maintaining current accommodative policy by looking past weak employment data, which could otherwise signal need for more accommodation

quotation: I thought President Rosengren also described interesting empirical work that suggests that a lot of individuals out of the labor market, including retirees, are likely to reenter the workforce as the expansion continues. And I think the bottom line of that—I'm not positive—is that there is more slack than what would be captured in U-3.
description: More labor market slack exists than captured by U-3 due to potential labor force reentry
explanation: Hidden slack from potential labor force reentry suggests the labor market has more capacity than headline unemployment indicates, supporting continued accommodation.

quotation: Assuming the coincidence of positive supply shocks will not be repeated this year, at least not as uniformly as last year, I expect an increase in core inflation even if the unemployment rate stays at its current level.
description: Core inflation expected to increase even if unemployment remains stable at current level
explanation: Expected inflation increase even with stable unemployment at current low levels suggests the labor market is already too tight, warranting restrictive policy.

quotation: When they respond to our questions about inflation, they say they are experiencing no inflationary pressures even though their wages are increasing 3 percent or so and their earnings are very good.
description: Manufacturing companies report no inflationary pressures despite 3% wage increases and good earnings
explanation: Wage increases not translating to inflation pressure suggests productivity gains are containing price pressures, supporting accommodative policy

quotation: the labor market is tight, and this should translate into higher wage gains in the year ahead
description: Tight labor market conditions should translate into higher wage gains in the coming year
explanation: Tight labor market leading to higher wages suggests inflationary pressures that warrant restrictive monetary policy to maintain price stability

quotation: I do think that there was a disconnect in the fourth quarter between the supply or output side and the demand side. If you look at the numbers for employment and hours, you would have certainly come up with a stronger forecast.
description: Employment and hours data indicated stronger economic conditions than output measures suggested
explanation: The observation that employment data suggested stronger underlying economic conditions than output data implies the economy may be more robust than headline numbers suggest, supporting continued policy tightening

quotation: To accommodate the expected increase in sales, our firms report that they will need to start adding staff before they need to expand capacity. But many believe that they can wait a while before doing either. One-fourth of the firms expecting sales growth will begin hiring workers this quarter, but almost 30 percent will wait until sometime in the second half of next year.
description: Businesses plan to delay hiring despite expected sales growth
explanation: Delayed hiring plans indicate weak labor demand and suggest the employment recovery will be gradual, supporting continued monetary accommodation

quotation: I expect the expansion to slow only slightly, due primarily to labor force constraints, but for inflation to maintain its downward tilt.
description: Economic expansion expected to slow due to labor force constraints
explanation: Labor force constraints limiting economic growth indicates very tight employment conditions where labor supply is the binding constraint, supporting restrictive policy to prevent overheating

quotation: Alaska is recovering at a rate of growth in employment that is twice that expected prior to [unintelligible] growth.
description: Strong employment recovery in Alaska exceeding expectations
explanation: Strong regional employment growth suggests economic momentum that could contribute to inflationary pressures, supporting tighter monetary policy

quotation: Perhaps even more encouraging are the signs that investment has begun to pick up and the signs of life in labor markets.
description: There are encouraging signs of life in national labor markets
explanation: Signs of life in labor markets indicate improving employment conditions nationally, which could support a move toward less accommodative monetary policy

quotation: I do worry a bit about the progress on productivity growth; that has been fairly discouraging. I may be wrong but, if you look at that closely, I think one of the major reasons behind that is obviously the employment growth.
